docTitle.titlePart: ABRAHAM LINCOLN HISTORICAL NOTE While the popular conception of Lincoln as the Liberator of the Slave is true historically , there is a deeper view of his life and character . He was the savior , if not the real creator , of the American Union of free Democratic States . His proclamation of emancipation was purely an incident of war . The first policy of his administration was to save the Union . To this fact we owe a united Nation to-day . It is this truth of history which I try to make a living reality in my play .

set.p: The scenes relating to the issues of our National life have been drawn from authentic records . The plot of the action is based on the letter of Colonel John Nicolay to Major Hay , dated August 25 , 1864 , in which the following opening paragraph is found :

titlePage.docImprint: “ Hell is to pay . TheNew Yorkpoliticians have got a stampede on that is about to swamp everything . Raymond and the National Committee are here to-day . R. thinks a Commission to Richmond is about the only salt to save us ; while the President sees and says it would be utter ruination . The matter is now undergoing consultation . Weak-kneed damned fools are in the movement for a new candidate to supplant the President . Everything is darkness , doubt , and discouragement . ”

set.p: No liberty has been taken with an essential detail of history in the development of the action except to slightly shift the dates of two incidents for dramatic unity . In neither case does the change of date affect the validity of the scene as used .

div.head: PROLOGUE
div.stage: SET SCENE : The rough-hewn log cabin of Tom Lincoln is seen in the center surrounded by the forest wilderness of Southern Indiana , 1820 .
The cabin door is cut in level with the ground . There is no shutter to the door and no window to the cabin .

Right and Left of the door opening are rude benches of split logs . On the walls are stretched a coon and a small bear , squirrel and muskrat skins . In the foreground on the right is seen an old-fashioned wash pot set on three stones . Near the wash pot is fixed in the ground a pole , on the top of which are hung six gourds cut for martin swallows to nest in . Beside it are a rude bench and two wash tubs . On the left is a crude settee made of a split log with legs set in augur holes and a rough back made of saplings . An old-fashioned doctor 's saddle-bags hang across the back of the settee . The trees are walnut , beech and oak — undergrowth of dogwood , sumac and wild grapevines . These vines , festooned over the cabin , give a sinister impression . A creek winds down through the hills behind the cabin .
AT RISE : SARAH is seen softly tiptoeing toward the cabin door . She pauses , listens and slowly peeps inside . She listens again and then slips away and calls .
Abe ! Abe !
[ SARAH goes back to the door and peeps in and runs to the gate . ]
Abe ——! Ma 's awake now !
[ She returns to the door , peeps in again and runs once more to the gate . ]
Abe ——! He 's feelin ’ her pulse ! Come on in — do n't stay out there in the woods ....
[ ABE enters slowly . ]
What does he say ?
He ai n't said nothin ’ yet .
He 's a dumb doctor , anyhow . I could n't get him to say a word comin ’ , last night .
Well , he 's here now , and there 's his saddle-bags full of medicine . You 've been ridin ’ all night — you look terrible tired ! Go to bed and sleep a little ——
I can n't — while Ma 's so sick — I 'm afraid to go to sleep ——
Why ——?
You know why — Sarah ——
Ah , she ai n't goin ’ to die now . She 's talkin ’ to the doctor — lie down just a little while and get to sleep before the sun comes up or ye can n't sleep ——
[ Pleading . ]
— come on ——
No — I 'm scared — the plague 's killin ’ folks every day — and nobody knows what to do for ‘ em ——
[ The DOCTOR and TOM enter from the cabin and come down slowly — the DOCTOR seems to be debating his course of action . ]
[ Eagerly to DOCTOR . ]
You can do somethin ’ for her , Doctor ?
[ Hesitates . ]
Yes — Get me a clean towel and a bowl ——
Run , SARAH — quick ——
[ Running to cabin . ]
Yes — I 'll get ‘ em ——
[ The DOCTOR opens his saddle-bags , takes out his lancet and examines its keen point . ]
What are ye goin ’ ter do with that knife ?
Bleed her , of course — it 's the only thing to do ——
[ Starts toward cabin . ]
[ To his father . ]
Do n't let him do it ——!
What 's that ?
You sha n't bleed her — I do n't know nothin ’ ‘ bout doctorin ’ — but I know that 'll kill her ——
I 've a notion to give you the worst cussin ’ you ever had in your life , Tom Lincoln ....
‘ Twould n't do no good — Doctor ——
[ Throwing his arms up . ]
‘ Twould do me good ! I 've rode all night — thirty-five miles — from my home in Kentucky across the Ohio , into this wilderness , just for you to insult me ——
I did n't mean to ——

Well , you 're doin ’ it — and I 'd give ye the cussin ’ that'ud pay me for my trouble comin ’ up here — if I had n't heard what you 've been doin ’ for your neighbors , in this plague . There 's no doctor in thirty miles —— You 've been the doctor and nurse — mother and father to ‘ em all . And when they die , you go into the woods , cut down a tree , rip out the boards , make the coffin , dig the grave and lower the dead with a prayer — I 'd like to cuss you , Tom Lincoln — but I can n't — damn ye ——!
I 'm sorry , Doctor — but I just could n't let ye bleed her ——
All right — good-by ——
[ With a snort of anger , the DOCTOR throws his lancet into his saddle-bags , snaps them together , and starts for the gate . ]
[ Following the DOCTOR to gate . ]
Doctor ——!
What do ye want ——?
[ Seizing his hand . ]
Please do n't go — I 'm mighty sorry we made ye mad — I did n't go to do it — you see ——
[ He falters . ]
I love my Ma so , I just could n't see ye cut her arm open . And Pa did n't mean to hurt yer feelin 's — wo n't ye stay and help us ? Ca n't ye do somethin ’ else for her ——?
[ Pauses . ]
I 'll pay ye ——! I 'll work for ye a whole — year ——
You 'd work for me a year ?
[ Eagerly . ]
I 'll work for ye five years if you 'll just save her — just save her life — that 's all — do n't go — please , do n't ——
[ The DOCTOR slips his arm around the boy , draws him close and holds him a moment . ]
You 're a good boy , Abe ——
You 'll stay ——?
I 'd stay and do something if I could , Sonny , but to tell ye the truth , I do n't know what to do — I 'm not quite sure I 'm right about the bleedin ’ , or I 'd stay and make you both help me ——
[ He pauses . ]

But I 'm not sure ——! I 'm not sure ! And I do n't know what else to do — I 've got no medicine — so I can n't stay . All I can tell ye is to keep her warm — and give her everything good to eat that she can take — she 's in God 's hands — Good-by ——
[ The DOCTOR hurries through the gate — and leaves ABE and TOM gazing forlornly after him , as SARAH comes from the house . ]
I 've got the towel and bowl all ready ——
[ Pauses . ]
What 's the matter ——?
[ Looks around . ]
Where 's the doctor ——?
He 's gone ——
Gone ——?
Yes ——
[ NANCY enters by door of cabin . ]

[ NANCY 'S sudden appearance in the door swings ABE around with a quick cry of pain . The sun is tinging the eastern sky with the splendor of an Indian Summer morning . The mother 's figure in blue homespun suggests against the dark background of the cabin door the coming of a spirit from the unseen world . She pauses a moment in the doorway and smiles at her son . ]
Oh , Ma , you must n't ——
[ Following . ]
Nancy ——!
I 'm better , I 'm a lot better ——
You 're too sick to come out here , Ma ——
[ Smiling . ]
I can walk — as well as you can ,— see ——
[ She sways slightly toward the settee . ]
But the Doctor says you must keep warm ——
Well — I have on the warm stockings that Sarah knit for me and the coon skin moccasins you made — do n't you see , I 'm better now ——?
[ Joyfully . ]
Look , Pa , she 's better !
Yes — she 's better !
[ Alarmed . ]
Do n't try to walk — set down , honey !
[ Sinking on bench . ]
Yes — I will ——
[ The boy comes closer , staring eagerly into his mother 's face . ]
Come closer , my boy ——
[ ABE kneels at her feet . ]
I 'm a feared of this , Nancy — you better let me git a hot rock and wrap it up for your feet .
Yes , Tom — and bring me the Bible . I want Abe to read to me .
[ TOM goes into the cabin worried over her . ]
Feel all right , Ma ——?
[ She nods and breathes deeply — her eyes alight . ]
I wanted to see the sun rise through the trees ! You remember the day you cut down your first tree to begin the clearing and the sunlight came through the hole you 'd made to the sky ——
Yes — I remember .
You called me to come and see it ——
[ In a whisper . ]
Yes ——
I was proud that morning as I saw you stand with your ax on that big log — anything my boy starts to do — he does ——
[ Pauses . ]
Your father taught you to use the ax and ——
[ Turns and looks at ABE . ]

Your father 's a good man , my son — kind-hearted and true and everybody likes him . They made him road supervisor of his township in Kentucky once . If he could read and write he would have gone to the legislature ——

[ TOM enters from the cabin with the rock and Bible , he crosses to NANCY , and ABE takes the rock and puts it under her feet — SARAH kneels and helps him . NANCY 'S hand drops on the bench . TOM picks up her hand , and the chill of it worries him . ]
[ ABE and SARAH rise . ]
Read to me , son — I like to hear your voice ——
[ Brightly . ]
All right — what ——?
The Twenty-third Psalm .
[ ABE looks for the place . ]
I love to hear you read , my boy . It means that you can do what any other man can — it means so much !
[ Reads . ]

The Lord is my shepherd — I shall not want . He maketh me to lie down in green pastures . He leadeth me beside still waters . He restoreth my soul . He leadeth me in the paths of righteousness for his name 's sake ——
[ In a whisper . ]
Yea , tho ’ I walk through the valley of the shadow of death , I will fear no evil , for thou art with me ——
[ ABE stops , looks up at his mother in amazement . ]
Ma ——

Remember always , my boy , that God is with you ! He is in the day and the night . He is in the sun and the wind , the trees and the grass — and not a sparrow falls to the ground without He knows . You recollect the year you put up those gourds there ——
[ She points to the pole . ]
for your martins ——? You cried when they circled away in the fall ——
[ ABE nods . ]
I told you God would send them back in the spring , did n't I ——?
[ She laughs softly . ]
You said that He 'd forget to tell them and they 'd never find the way — but they came — did n't they ——?
Yes , Ma , and I know now they 'll come again next spring .

So — I want you never again to doubt God , my boy , and I want you never to doubt yourself . Your bare feet , your ragged clothes , how poor you are — this is nothing ! It does n't count here — it 's what you feel , it 's what you believe — it 's what you see that counts ! I 've taught you to read and write , and now you can do anything ! If God takes me ——
[ She pauses exhausted . ]
But you must n't say that , Ma ——!
“ The judgments of the Lord are true and righteous altogether ! ”
No ! no , Ma ! Do n't talk that way ! You 'll give up if you do ——!
If He calls , my son , then my work is done — and you can do all I 've tried and failed to do ——
[ Alarmed . ]
Had she better talk so much , Pa ——
[ Stoops to fix her feet . ]
[ Feeling her hand . ]
Nancy ——!
Just a minute more , Tom ——! Do n't let him know yet — you know ——!
[ With upward look of faith . ]
Yes , I know ——
[ To ABE . ]
It 's all right — boy ——

Come back close , my son , I want to tell you something I saw last night ! I had a dream — the same one I had the night before you were born . You had grown a man — strong and brave — wise and gentle . The people hung on your words , and did you homage . But you remembered this cabin here in the deep woods and you were humble . I walked with you between two white pillars . It was still and solemn , in there . Outside I could hear the people calling your name . You bowed low and whispered in my ear : “ This is all yours , my Mother . I bought it for you with my life . All that I am I owe to you —— ”
[ Her voice sinks to a whisper that is half a laugh of religious ecstasy . ]
[ Joyfully . ]
See how she 's smilin ’ — Pa ! She 's getting well — I tell you ——!
[ Whispering . ]
Do n't ye understand , boy ——?
No — what ——?
What — what is it ——?
[ In deep religious awe . ]
Look — look at her eyes ——! She 's not telling ye a dream — she 's looking through the gates of Heaven ——
No — no — no ——!
It 's death — boy — it 's come — Lord , God , have mercy ——

[ ABE springs to his feet and stares in anguish , as TOM falls on his knees beside NANCY . NANCY 'S hand rests gently on TOM 'S shaggy head , while he sobs . With her other hand she feels for ABE 'S and holds it feebly . ]
Be good to your Father ,——
[ She pauses and breathes with difficulty . ]
In the days to come , he will be the child and you the man ——
Yes ——
And love your sister ——
[ ABE nods . ]
If dark hours come , my spirit will be watching , my son — and I 'll help you if I can ——
Yes , I know it !
And remember that you can be a great man in this free country if you only say — I will ——
[ NANCY 'S body sinks in death as the boy lifts his face illumined by the light of a great purpose . ]
Yes , Ma ,— I will !

div.head: ACT I

stage.stage: SET SCENE : The President 's room in the White House , August 23 , 1864 . A flat desk left center . At right a long table and chairs . Doors open right and left . Large windows open center . Beside the center window stands an upright desk . In one corner a rack with map rollers and folios of maps on the floor and leaning against the wall .

AT RISE : Colonel Nicolay , the President 's Secretary , is seen writing before an enormous pile of mail . He reads a letter and throws it down in disgust . Reads another and hurls it into the waste basket . He rises — turns back to the desk and hurls an armful of the letters into the corner on the floor and removes enough letters to clear a space for his Chief to write .

div.stage: EDWARD enters dragging a mail bag .

sp.speaker: Edward !
sp.p: EDWARD

lg.l: NICOLAY
Hold that door tight this morning ——

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Tight as a drum , sir ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: If any men of importance try to crowd in before their time ——

lg.l: I 'll look out for them , sir — here 's another bag of letters , Colonel
Nicolay ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Another ——?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: And there 's two more outside ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: My God ——!

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Do n't blame me , sir — I did n't write ‘ em ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: No , I 'll vouch for your loyalty to the President .

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Where 'll I put these ——?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Throw the bag in the corner — there 's no room on his desk now ——

p.stage: EDWARD throws the bag in the corner of the room where NICOLAY has already piled the letters from the desk , and turns to NICOLAY . He watches NICOLAY destroying letters for a moment .

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Well , Edward ——?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Will you tell me one thing , Colonel Nicolay ——?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: If I can ——

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: What do they say in these letters to the President ——? I 've served through four administrations — I 've never seen such piles of letters in the White House before ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Well , Edward — these letters ask two things of Abraham Lincoln : That he dismiss General Grant from command of the Army ——

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: The idiots ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: And stop the war to-day — August 23 , 1864 ,— make peace — peace at any price — to-day ——

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: God save us ! After nearly four years — quit , with nothing settled ——?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: That 's what these letters demand ——

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: You could n't believe it —— No wonder his eyes sink back in his head , an ’ he looks as if he were seeing ghosts ——

div.stage: Pauses and starts .

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Watch out for that door , Edward ——

div.stage: EDWARD bows , and exits to door leading to the main corridor . NICOLAY returns to his task of reading the letters — one he tosses into the basket wearily — one he crumples in anger and hurls into the basket .

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: The fools ——!He is absorbed in a letter when MRS. LINCOLN enters in a state of nervous excitement . He rises quickly , and goes to meet her .What is it , Mrs. Lincoln ——?

lg.l: I have just heard that the Republican National Committee is in
Washington ——!

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: They are ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: In conference at Senator Winter 's house ——?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Yes ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: What do they want ?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: There are ugly rumors ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: What ——? What ——? What ——?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: I can n't discuss it , Madam , until the Chief knows ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Mr. Lincoln does n't know ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Not yet . He will , this morning . They 've just sent a demand to me that he see them before his public reception begins ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: You 've heard something — you know something — tell me — I can n't endure the suspense ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Only rumors — and they 're too ugly to put into words — they 're incredible ——

lg.l: All the same , you believe them ——
What have you heard ——?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Shakes his head .The Chief would n't like it if I talk , before he knows . I 'll tell you a few things I 'm thinking in plain English — if you 'd like to hear ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: You can n't make it too plain to suit me ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: In my opinion , the devil is to pay . Weak-kneed fools are deserting the Chief . Every man who loves Abraham Lincoln must get off his coat now and fight . He is the only man who can save this Nation to-day , and he 's too big and generous to be trusted alone with wolves ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: What can you mean ——? The Republican National Committee have no power over the President of the United States ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: No , Madam —— But they have certain powers over the Nominee of their party ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: But Mr. Lincoln is already the nominee of his party for the second term ... chosen two months ago — and the election is but eight weeks off — what do you mean ——?

div.stage: EDWARD enters .

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Miss Betty Winter to see you , Ma'am ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: How fortunate — they 're at her father 's house ——!

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Yes ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Show her right in here , Edward ——

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Yes , Madam ——

lg.l: And she 's loyal to Mr. Lincoln —
Right this way ,— Miss Betty ——

div.stage: BETTY enters — a young woman 25 years old — poised , cultured , charming .

lg.l: Welcome — my child ——

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: You 're always so kind ——!

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Excuse me , ladies — while I go out and get rid of some of these people waiting to see the President ——

div.stage: NICOLAY exits .

lg.l: Tell me , dear , you 've heard something — the Republican National
Committee are at your father 's ——

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: They were there — they 've adjourned to Thaddeus Stevens ’ house across the street from us —— They were locked in with father for two hours ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Locked in ——?

lg.l: With the keyhole chinked up ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: And you did n't get a hint of what they 're up to ——?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Not the faintest ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Oh , Betty — they 're discussing me ——

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: They did n't mention your name ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: How do you know ——?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Well — I did hear a little ——! I could hear from the next room when they got excited ! It 's Abraham Lincoln they 're discussing — not his wife ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: You 're sure ——?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Sure ——! It sounded like a regular dog fight — with one big brute howling ——Imitates .— the President 's name above the din ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: But , you can n't be sure , my dear ——

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: What on earth could they be discussing you for ——?

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: My loyalty , of course — you know that my brothers are in the Southern Army , fighting the Union . Fools have accused me of giving them important secrets of the Government . When I hate them for all they have done to me and mine ——!

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: But my dear Mrs. Lincoln — no one believes such lies about you now — not even in this bitter campaign — it 's absurd ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Hesitates .That is not the real thing I 'm afraid of , child — it 's something worse — I 'm going to take you into my confidence now — may I ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: I 'll be tickled to death with the honor ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: And I 'm going to ask you to help me ——

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: I 'll be in the Cabinet next ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: The truth is , I owe A. T. Stewart and Company an enormous bill for dresses —$ 60 , 000 ——

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Sixty thousand — oh , my Lord ! That 's worse than mine ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: I had to get them ! The world said the White House would be disgraced by my awkward husband 's régime — I 've shown them better ! But I just could n't tell Mr. Lincoln . He has no idea of the cost of clothes . If these jackals have found out and attack him on my account , the thought of it will kill me ——

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: But you know he 'd defend you against any one who dares attack you .

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Yes , dear — but it would hurt him so to hear it from their brutal lips . I want you to find out from your father , if they know ——

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: And if they know ——?

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Get here before they do , and I 'll head them off — I 'll tell Mr. Lincoln first ——

lg.l: On one condition — that you help me ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Anything you ask ——

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: I 've promised my fiancé that I would get an appointment for him to see the President on something very important ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Mr. Lincoln will be here in a few minutes . I 'll have him see your sweetheart first ——

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: But — it 's a personal matter and he does n't wish to come to a public reception . He wants an hour alone —— Could you get it for him , to-night ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: I — think — so ——

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: You 'll try ——?

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: I 'll do it , child — certainly ! You 're one loyal friend we have in that crowd of wolves on the Capitol Hill ——

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: All right , I 'll find out if they 're discussing politics or your dressmaker 's bill .

div.stage: BETTY hurries to the door , followed by MRS. LINCOLN .

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: God bless you , child ——

div.stage: NICOLAY enters by the other door .

lg.l: BETTY
If it 's dresses — I 'll beat them to the White House !

div.stage: BETTY exits .

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: The President is coming , Madam ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: I 'm going . But I may want to see him before that Committee — in case I send in — see that he comes , will you ?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: I 'll try to manage it . The friends of the Chief may call on you for some inside work , Madam .

lg.l: I 'll do my part , never fear !

div.stage: MRS. LINCOLN exits and NICOLAY hastily arranges his desk and stands at attention as LINCOLN enters .
LINCOLN crosses the room with long nervous stride , reaches his desk , looks at the pile of letters and shakes his head wearily .

lg.l: Sorry for you , John , with all these letters on your hands ——
You have to work ——!

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: I 'm trying to get them out of your way , sir ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Thank you — you know the ones I want to see ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Yes , sir ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Softly .And do n't forget that no man or woman can be turned from that door , who comes here to ask for the saving of a human life ——Pauses .There 's a firing squad shooting a boy down in Virginia this morning ——!Shakes his head .I hope I did n't do wrong to let them . Somehow I could not find an excuse to save him ——Sighs .The Generals are all after me about my pardons ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: The Secretary of War is out there now , champing his bit , to head you off on some of them , I think ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Do n't let old Mars in yet . He 's no business here at this hour . Let him paw a hole in the ground .Pauses .Any news from the front , this morning ?

lg.l: From General Grant 's lines — only this , sir ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Reads .“ Confederate Cavalry raiders capture a Brigadier General and fifty army mules . ” — Too bad — rush a regiment after the mules — they 're worth $ 200 a piece — Jeff Davis can have my Brigadier General ——!

lg.l: Yes , sir — and this came in code from Sherman —

div.stage: Hands LINCOLN another telegram .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Eagerly .Word from Sherman ! Good !Reads .— “ Scouts report Hood 's trenches before Atlanta are impregnable — carefully considering a flank movement — but as yet , I cannot find the position or strength of Hood 's second line —— ” W. T. Sherman ——Pauses .Grant 's deadlocked with Lee at Petersburg — If-Sherman-could-only-give-us-Atlanta !——Pauses .I 've a notion to telegraph Sherman an order direct ——!

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: I would n't go over General Grant 's head , sir , with a military order — he 's sensitive ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: It might make trouble — Grant might resent my interference with his plan of campaign ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: It would have to be filed in the War Department ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Yes — I know . Anything else ——?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Handing him a large document .Baker 's full report of the secret service on the Copperhead Societies —— He asks for the immediate arrest of their leaders — and I think he 's right ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Shakes his head .It wo n't do — it wo n't do just now — it 's an ugly business — too ugly for haste — I 'll look it over carefully ——Lays the report on his desk .I 'm ready now to see the people ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: The Republican National Committee are in town , sir ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: What on earth are they doing here ——?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: That 's what everybody 's asking ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: They should be in their States , leading the Party to victory —— What do they want ?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: To see you ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Umph ——!

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Henry Raymond , their Chairman , is with them , and has just sent word demanding a hearing before your public reception this morning .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Make the appointment later . They 're all distinguished men . They can wait while the humbler people have their turn . I came up here from the wilderness . I know what it means to have the great rush by me ——Laughs .No — I 'll see the common folks first ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: I think you 'd better see this Committee right away , sir ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Why ——? What have you heard ——?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Some ugly rumors ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Spare me the rumors ! We 've enough of them flying around Washington to poison us all . They can only wish me to hedge on some of my principles in this crisis . I 've made all the campaign statements I 'm going to make . I 've faith in the good sense of the people . I 'm going to plant my feet squarely on that faith and wait the verdict of this election ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: You wo n't see the Committee now ——?

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: No ——! I 'll take my bath of public opinion first . I want to see real men and women and feel their hearts beat close to mine . It tones me up for the day 's work — let them in .

div.stage: STANTON bursts into the room in a towering rage .

sp.speaker: STANTON
sp.p: Mr. President , I 've been kept waiting !Confronting NICOLAY .NICOLAY turns away and laughs .Nicolay ! How dare you keep me waiting in an anteroom , while you talk to the President ! I want you to understand , sir , that as Secretary of War , I 've the right to enter this room at any hour , day or night , announced or unannounced , and by God , I 'm going to exercise that privilege !

div.stage: STANTON paces the floor furiously .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Laughing .Well , you 're here now , and it 's all right , Stanton — Easy ! Easy , or we 'll have to put some rocks in your pocket to hold you down . What can I do ——?

sp.speaker: STANTON
sp.p: Mr. President , I 've come here this morning to make a square issue with you on the abuse of the pardoning power which you are making daily ——

lg.l: As Chief Magistrate of the people , I have been clothed with that power ,
Stanton ——

sp.speaker: STANTON
sp.p: Angrily .You have no right to exercise it under the present conditions ! Discipline in our armies must be maintained . You are hamstringing me and every General in the field — by suspending the death penalty of our Courts-Martial . Men are deserting in thousands and we 've got to put a stop to it .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: That 's what I say ——! Bring to me the traitors who are causing them to desert , and see what I 'll do to them !

sp.speaker: STANTON
sp.p: You can n't evade the issue I 'm making , sir ! You 'll be asked this morning to pardon a deserter . I call a halt here and now — will you stop to-day the use of this pardoning power ——?

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I 've got to hear both sides — it 's my solemn duty ——

lg.l: All right , I 'm done . There 's my resignation as your Secretary of
War — Good-by !

div.stage: STANTON strides angrily to the door and LINCOLN speaks as he puts his hand on the knob .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Wait a minute ——

sp.speaker: STANTON
sp.p: It 's no use ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Come back here . I 've something to say to you .

div.stage: STANTON returns .

sp.speaker: STANTON
sp.p: You 're wasting your breath ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Stanton , I appointed you Secretary of War against the advice of every man about me . You were a cantankerous Democrat and my enemy . You had said the meanest things about me that were ever spoken in Washington — and that 's putting it pretty strong . You called me a low clown — the original gorilla . In spite of all this , I saw your great qualities ! I saw that you were absolutely fearless and absolutely honest , that your nerves were made of steel and your capacity for work was boundless . Even in your passions and hatreds , you showed a loyalty to the Union that rose above the parties and creeds of a lifetime . I like men of your strong personality . They stand between a nation and hell . And so , I appointed you , my bitter foe , to my cabinet . I 've never regretted it for a minute in these years of blood and anguish . You 've made the best Secretary of War this country ever had . In spite of your mean traits and your awful profanity , I 've learned to love you ! Now , you 've resigned , and done your duty , as you see it . I 've accepted your resignation , conscripted you again , and reappointed you ——!Pauses and strokes his shoulder .Go back to your desk and stick to the rules — that 's your business ; and I 'll keep right on here tempering Justice with Mercy when I get a chance .

lg.stage: Gazing at him a moment hopelessly .
lg.l: Well ,— I suppose I 'll have to try ——!
But — I 'm — damned — if — you — interfere — with — me — again !

div.stage: STANTON hurries to the door .

lg.l: All right now —— But look here , Stanton ——
If I have to send over a pardon or two to you this morning ——

sp.speaker: STANTON
sp.p: Hell fire !

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Easy — easy now ! You 'll know they 're very urgent , and will admit of no delay on account of red tape ——

p.stage: Throws his hands up in wild gesture of despair .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: John , the old Fox was trying to head me off , was n't he ——? Get them in here quick — who 's the first in turn ——?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: A young lady to plead for the life of her brother ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Bring her in !As NICOLAY goes to the door , LINCOLN follows to meet the young woman . She enters , a forlorn little figure with baby face and blonde hair . She is plainly dressed in homespun cloth and does not wear hoopskirts . The President greets her with the utmost deference .Taking both her hands .My dear young lady — I 'm glad to see you — good old Pennsylvania Dutch ! I knew you before you spoke — my folks came down to Virginia from there , in the old Colonial days ——

lg.l: Oh — Meester — Presiden — you are so goot to me — you are so kind ——
I haf no speech ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Come now , tell me in your own way what I can do to help you ——

sp.speaker: THE SISTER
sp.p: Oh — Meester Presiden — you can do all — you can do any t'ing — und I am so happy to see you — I cannot begin ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Soothing her .Take your time , little girl — all the others will have to wait on you now ——

sp.speaker: THE SISTER
sp.p: Ya-ya — it is my turn now — ya , und I must hurry . You see , it 's mine brudder — he ist just von leetle poy , Meester Presiden — von leetle poy with curly hair like mine ——

div.stage: She chokes .

lg.l: And what happened to him , my dear ?

sp.speaker: THE SISTER
sp.p: Vell , you see he lif wid me in Pennsylvania — ve are all alone to-gedder — und he lef me und go into der armee — und von bad man he giv him a leetle book vot tell him to desert und go home to his peoples — I haf dot leetle book , Meester Presiden ——She hands him the book .Und my brudder he 's such a leetle poy , he read und he tink vot ze book say is so , und he leef ze armee und come home und kiss me und say , “ I vill take care of you now , mein seester —— ”Breaks down .Und zey come und take heem , und now he is to be shot ——

div.stage: She chokes .
LINCOLN reads the title of the little book .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: “ Why should Brothers Fight ? ” “ By Richard Vaughan ” — an old Copperhead leader I 'll warrant !Pauses .And you came to me , all alone , little girl ?

sp.speaker: THE SISTER
sp.p: Ya — I haf no friens here ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Your Congressman does not know of this ?

div.stage: NICOLAY begins to make out the pardon .

sp.speaker: THE SISTER
sp.p: I do not know ze Congress-man — mein leetle brudder is all I haf ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Alone , friendless — with no Congressman to speak for you ! Well , little girl , you do n't need anybody to speak for you — you speak for yourself — you 're good and honest and love your brother — and by jings , you do n't wear hoopskirts — I 'm sorry to rile old Stanton again ——Laughs .But I 'm going to pardon your brother ——!

lg.l: Oh — Meester Presiden — I praise ze good God ——
There ! There ! Now , do n't do that , you 'll have me crying in a minute and
John Nicolay here will see me ——

sp.speaker: THE SISTER
sp.p: Ya ! Meester Nicolay — wo n't mind — he so kind to me too ——

div.stage: NICOLAY has prepared the pardon and the President signs and hands it to her .

lg.l: Wiz all my heart !

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: To NICOLAY .Send her to Stanton , and tell him to rush that order to stay the execution . They shall not shoot this poor boy , ignorant of our laws , but if he can find the man who put that little book ——Holds up book .into his hand , advising desertion — I 'll hang him on a gallows forty cubits high !

div.stage: He lays the booklet on his desk .
NICOLAY writes on the back of the pardon .

lg.l: Mein brudder he vill go back und he vill be von goot poy for you ,
Meester Presiden ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Yes , I know he will , my child , I know he will . Good-by , and God bless you .

sp.speaker: THE SISTER
sp.p: Und God bless you , Meester Presiden ——!

div.stage: NICOLAY pauses at the door and gives orders to the doorman .

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Edward , take her to the War Office with this message ——

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Yes , sir ——

sp.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
sp.p: I demand to see the President at once ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: I can n't admit you , Mr . Congressman , just now ——

lg.l: I demand it , sir ——

div.stage: LINCOLN crosses to the door .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: What is it , John ——

sp.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
sp.p: Mr. President , I have been here three times ! I demand the right to see you — to ask the pardon of one of my constituents .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: All right ! Out with it !

sp.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
sp.p: He is one of the solid citizens of Massachusetts ; a slave trader whose ship has been confiscated . He has spent five years in prison , and cannot pay the heavy fine in money imposed —— He is not a bad man at heart .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: And he wants me to pardon him — this slave-trader ——!

sp.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
sp.p: I ask it as a matter of justice — he has paid the penalty — five long years in prison ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Laughs .I might pardon a murderer from old Massachusetts , she 's done glorious service in this war — but a man who can make a business of going to Africa and robbing her of helpless men , women and children and selling them into bondage ——!He pauses and stiffens .— before that man can have liberty by any act of mine , he can stay in jail and rot !

lg.l: Now , you 've got it ——!
Yes — I heard it ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Turning back to his desk , and examining his papers .Good —— Bring in the next one , John !As NICOLAY exits with the Congressman who continues to talk in loud tones , a sweet little girl of twelve slips by and reaches the President 's desk unannounced . The President has taken his seat and is writing . While the President continues to write , the little girl slips close and watches him wistfully . He lifts his head , sees her , and smiles .Why , what a wee girl — and you got in here all by yourself ——?

sp.speaker: VIRGINIA
sp.p: I slipped in when no one was looking ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Did you ? What did you do that for ?

sp.speaker: VIRGINIA
sp.p: I was afraid they would n't let me in , if they knew what I wanted ——

lg.l: And what do you want ?

sp.speaker: VIRGINIA
sp.p: If you please , sir — a pass to go through the lines to Virginia — my brother 's there — he was shot in the last battle — and I want to see him .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Of course , you do — and you shall too .

div.stage: He seizes his pen , writes a pass and hands it to her .

lg.l: Oh , thank you — thank you !

lg.stage: Casually placing his hand on her head .
lg.l: Of course , you 're loyal ——?

div.stage: VIRGINIA 'S lips quiver , she hesitates , looks up into his face through dimmed eyes , and her slender body stiffens as she slowly speaks .

sp.speaker: VIRGINIA
sp.p: Yes — loyal — with all my heart — to Virginia !

div.stage: The trembling little fingers hand the pass back as the tears roll down her cheeks . LINCOLN looks away to hide from her his own emotion , stoops and takes her hand in his . His voice is low and tender and full of feeling .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I know what it cost you to say that , child . You 're a brave little girl ! And I 'll love you always for this glimpse you 've given me of a great spirit and a great people . That 's why I can n't let the South go —— They can n't leave this Union . We need them —— Now I can trust you ——?

p.stage: NICOLAY enters with a young mother and baby and hesitates at sight of the little girl .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Come on in , John — it 's all right . I 'm about through with this young lady ——NICOLAY brings the young mother to the desk and LINCOLN takes VIRGINIA down stage .Come down here , dear , so old man Nicolay can n't hear us — he might n't understand .He sits on a chair and draws the girl close .You see , I understand you — and can trust you implicitly . Now if I give you back this and let you go — will you promise me that no word shall pass your lips of what you 've seen inside our lines ?

sp.speaker: VIRGINIA
sp.p: Oh , yes — I promise ——!

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Handing her the pass .May God speed the day , child , when your people and mine shall no longer be enemies ——

sp.speaker: VIRGINIA
sp.p: Thank you , sir !

lg.l: Run now !
lg.stage: VIRGINIA exits . At the door she throws him a kiss .
LINCOLN comes quickly to the mother and greets her cheerily .
lg.l: Well , little mother , what 's the matter ?

div.stage: She hesitates and appeals to NICOLAY .

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Tell him yourself ——

sp.speaker: THE MOTHER
sp.p: Trembling .If you please , sir , we ai n't been married but a little over a year , and my husband 's never seen the baby ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: That 's too bad ——

sp.speaker: THE MOTHER
sp.p: He 's in the army and I could n't stand it any longer — so I came down to Washington to get a pass to take the baby to him . But he would n't let me have it at the War Office ——

lg.l: I 'll bet old Mars would n't — Phew !
What do you say . John — let 's send her down ?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: The strictest orders have been issued to allow no more women to go to the front ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Humph ——! Well , I 'll tell you what we can do — give her husband a leave of absence , and let him come up here to see them !

lg.l: You do n't mind my laughing , do you ? I just can n't help it — I can n't stop !
I can n't stop laughing !

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Laugh and cry as much as you please — but tell me where are you stopping ?

sp.speaker: THE MOTHER
sp.p: Nowhere yet , sir ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: How 's that ?

sp.speaker: THE MOTHER
sp.p: I went straight from the depot to the War Office and then I just walked the street blind with crying till I made up my mind to come here .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: We 'll fix that then ! Nicolay will write you an order that will take you and your baby to a good hospital and care for you till your husband comes — and fix it so he can stay here a week with you ——

lg.l: I just can n't thank you ! I 'm so happy , all I can do is to laugh !

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Laugh on , little mother — and off with you now — clear out !

div.stage: The mother goes out laughing .
NICOLAY shows the little mother out and returns to LINCOLN .

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: The deputation of colored men whom you asked to come this morning are waiting , sir — will you see them now ?

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: At once ——

div.stage: LINCOLN turns to his desk and takes up a document containing his plan of Colonization and examines it as NICOLAY and three well-dressed colored men enter . They are typical Africans .

lg.l: Mr. President ——!
Our Father Abraham ——
We salute our Savior !

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Welcome , my friends . I have sent for you this morning to place in your hands a copy of my plan for colonization and to ask your help ——

sp.speaker: FIRST NEGRO
sp.p: Yes , sir ——

div.stage: The ebony faces with their cream white teeth showing in smiles and their wide rolling eyes make a striking contrast to the rugged face and poise of the President .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Your race is suffering , in my judgment , the greatest wrong inflicted on any people . But even when you cease to be slaves , you are yet far removed from being placed on an equality with the white race . On this broad continent , not a single man of your race is made the equal of a single man of ours ——

sp.speaker: FIRST NEGRO
sp.p: It 's so — yes , it 's so ——!

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Go where you are treated best and the ban is still upon you . I cannot alter it if I would . It is better for us both , therefore , to be separated . For the sake of your people you should sacrifice something of your present comfort .

sp.speaker: FIRST NEGRO
sp.p: Let our great leader show us the way ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: The Colony of Liberia is an old one , and it is open to you . I am now arranging to open another in Central America . You are intelligent and know that success does not so much depend on external help as on self-reliance . If you will engage in the enterprise I will spend the money Congress has entrusted to me for this purpose . I ask you to consider it seriously , not for yourselves merely , nor for your race and ours for the present time , BUT FOR THE GOOD OF MANKIND .

sp.speaker: FIRST NEGRO
sp.p: We will , sir ——!

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: The practical thing I want to ascertain is whether I can get a number of able-bodied men with their wives and children to go at once — men who “ can cut their own fodder ” so to speak ——? Take this plan , show it to your people ——Hands the document to the First Negro .— and find this out for me ——

sp.speaker: FIRST NEGRO
sp.p: We 'll do our best ——

lg.l: Praise God forever for our Savior-Leader ——!

div.stage: NICOLAY ushers out the three Negroes and shows in a stately black-robed figure in mourning for her dead . She walks quietly to the President and extends her hand with a gracious smile .

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: Perhaps I 've done wrong to take up your time ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: My time belongs to the people , Madam ——

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: I 've come to you , Mr. President , under an impulse I could not resist . Mr. Stoddard , your third Secretary , is my friend . He told me this morning that all night the sound of your footfall came from this room . He heard it at nine , at ten , at eleven . At midnight the Secretary of War left the door ajar and the steady tramp came with heavier sound . The last thing he heard at three was the muffled beat upstairs . The guard said it had not stopped at daylight . I saw you staggering alone under a Nation 's sorrow and I wondered if you had been given the vision to see the dawn of a new life for our people . I know I 'm looking into the eyes of the man whose word can stop this war and divide the Union — I have come to tell you that I lost my first born son at Fredericksburg — a lad of twenty ——She pauses and LINCOLN bends and presses her hand .May God help you in your trials , Mr. President , as he has helped me in mine ——

lg.l: You lost your first born at Fredericksburg and come to say this to me ?

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: And I 've been praying for you , day and night since ——

lg.l: Will you say that again , Madam ——

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: I have been praying for you , day and night , and I 've come this morning to bring you this message — Be strong and courageous , and God will bring the Nation through !

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: You say this to me — standing beside the grave of your son ?

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: And beside the cot of my other boy of sixteen who was dangerously wounded in General Grant 's last battle . I am proud of two such sons to lay on the altar of my country . I had to tell you that I 'm praying for you .

div.stage: LINCOLN closes both hands over hers and holds them a moment in silence .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: With upward gaze .How strange that you should come to me in this black hour with such a message . I 've often wondered if the soul of my mother were not speaking to me ! The day she died in the woods of Indiana , she told me that if dark hours came , her spirit would be watching , and she 'd help me if she could ! While you were talking to me — I got the tremor of her voice and the quiver of her lips — how strange !Looking down into her face .Thank you , Madam ! You have brought me medicine for both body and soul .LINCOLN presses her hand again and she quietly goes as he gazes after her .NICOLAY starts to follow her to the door — LINCOLN lifts his hand .John , I 'm rested now — I 'm ready for any work ——!

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: The National Committee have just arrived , sir .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: All right — let them in !LINCOLN resumes his place beside his desk and the Committee headed by HENRY RAYMOND , Editor of the New York Times , enter and solemnly range themselves about the President .To HENRY RAYMOND — taking his hand formally .Raymond , this is an unexpected honor you and your Committee do me . I thought you were at your desk in the Times office pouring hot shot into the flanks of our enemies , and the boys were all at home fighting for the victory that must be ours on the first Tuesday in November . Not that you 're unwelcome . You are the leaders of public opinion . The people rule this country , and I am their servant — what is it ——?

sp.speaker: RAYMOND
sp.p: You may be sure , Mr. President , that our mission is of the gravest importance . These gentlemen have brought such startling reports from their several states as to the bitterness and closeness of the fight , that they have reached a unanimous conclusion ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: And that is ——?

lg.l: That with your personality and record against General McClellan 's , your
Democratic opponent — the election for us is lost .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Your statement is blunt . But , as I have been renominated for a second term , my administration has been endorsed by our party , and the election is only eight weeks off — there is but one conclusion possible — and that is , that you should roll up your sleeves and get to work .

sp.speaker: RAYMOND
sp.p: The National Committee , Mr. President , has reached a different conclusion ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Yes ——?

sp.speaker: RAYMOND
sp.p: In view of your unpopularity , in view of the criticism of your policies , and your conduct of the war — they have decided to ask you to withdraw from the ticket and permit them to name a new candidate ——

lg.l: RAYMOND
I have stated it bluntly ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: And this is your unanimous verdict , gentlemen ——?

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Paces the floor a moment and then faces the Committee .It surpasses human belief ! Future generations will hold it incredible — that you , my party leaders , should heap this insult upon the man who led you to your first and only victory . That you should come here to-day to ask me to quit under fire , to sacrifice without a blow all I hold worth fighting for on this earth ——!

sp.speaker: RAYMOND
sp.p: The Committee made their request solely on the ground of patriotic duty — and ask you for the sacrifice upon the same grounds . They have found it impossible to defend your policies ——

lg.l: RAYMOND
Understand me , Mr. President — I am telling you the conclusion of this
Committee ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: All right , Raymond — fire away — spare me the oratory , please — just give me the plain reasons , one at a time , why you wish me to get off the ticket ——

sp.speaker: RAYMOND
sp.p: The first policy found indefensible has been your handling of the border slave states of Maryland , Kentucky and Missouri . You have not yet declared the slaves free in these states , the only ones in which you actually have the power to do so — at all .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: The first policy of my Administration has been to save for the Union the great border states — for the simple reason — with these border slave states , we have such a balance of power that the Union may be saved ! Without these states , the Union cannot be saved ! Therefore in my Proclamation of Emancipation , I purposely did not raise the question of the right or wrong of slavery . If slavery is not wrong , nothing is wrong . But the Constitution of the United States , which I have sworn to uphold in the border states of Maryland , Kentucky and Missouri , guarantees to their people the right to hold slaves if they choose .

sp.speaker: RAYMOND
sp.p: But why pat on the back the slaveholder of Maryland and strike at the slaveholder of South Carolina ?

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Because Maryland is loyal to the Union , and South Carolina is fighting it . My Proclamation was not a sermon on the rights of man — black or white . It was an act of war — a blow aimed at the heart of the seceding South to break its wealth and power , end the war , and save the Union . I know the spell of State loyalty in the South , gentlemen . I was born there . Many a mother in Richmond wept the day our flag fell from their Capitol . But they brushed their tears away and sent their sons to the front the next day , to fight that flag — in the name of Virginia ! So would thousands of mothers in these border slave states , if I put them to the test . In God 's own time slavery will be destroyed . I have saved these states for our cause by conciliation and compromise . I will not apologize for this act .He lifts his hand to stop interruption .My paramount object is to save the Union , and not , either to save or destroy slavery . If I could save the Union , without freeing a slave , I would do it . And if I could save it by freeing all the slaves , I would do it . And if I could save it by freeing some and leaving others alone , I would also do that . What I do about slavery and the colored race , I do because I believe it helps to save this Union !Pauses and faces his accusers .I 'll test this question right here — will the three Committeemen from Kentucky , Missouri and Maryland stand up for a minute ?The three Committeemen rise .Will the gentleman from Kentucky tell me what would have been the effect if I had included his state in my proclamation freeing the slaves ——? THE KENTUCKY COMMITTEEMAN The state would have seceded from the Union , sir .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Just so , and in Missouri ? THE MISSOURI COMMITTEEMAN The Legislature would have joined the Confederacy within twenty-four hours .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: And Maryland ——? THE MARYLAND COMMITTEEMAN Maryland would have promptly cut the railroads leading into Washington , isolated the Capital and joined the South .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: And with the loss of our Capital , Europe , eager to strike , would have recognized the Confederacy , would they not ? THE MARYLAND COMMITTEEMAN Undoubtedly , sir ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: So I hold —— THE MARYLAND COMMITTEEMAN Our State believed you when you said in your Inaugural : “ I have no purpose directly or indirectly to interfere with the institution of slavery in the states where it exists ! ”

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Then you three gentlemen , at least , are with me on this issue ?

sp.speaker: ALL THREE
sp.p: Yes —! Yes —! Yes —!

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I thought so ——

div.stage: To Raymond .

sp.speaker: What next ?
sp.p: RAYMOND Your plan to colonize the Negro race as expressed in your Proclamation of Emancipation and in the bill which you have had passed through Congress has hurt your best friends ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: And why should it ? My views on that subject were known to all men before you nominated me first in Chicago , four years ago . I said then that I believed there is a sharp physical difference between the white and black races , and I have always linked colonization with freedom . The Negro cannot remain in a free democracy unless we absorb him into our social and political life . Therefore , we must colonize him . We owe it to ourselves , we owe it to future generations — above all , we owe it to the Negro himself . He was brought here by cruel force . At our own expense , therefore , we should return him to the home of his fathers , and build there a free republic for his children . We should give him our language and our ideals , and we should give him millions of our money , until he can stand alone . We must face this problem squarely now .

sp.speaker: RAYMOND
sp.p: Yet you compromise on other issues .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Only because I must to save the Union . Trim and hedge on this issue , and future generations will feel their way back to it through blood and tears . I have always held that the happiness and progress of this Union of Free Democratic States will be secure only in the separation of the white and black races , and I will not eat my words !——Pauses .— the next charge in your bill of indictment , gentlemen ?

sp.speaker: RAYMOND
sp.p: I now present the Hon . Thaddeus Stevens , leader of Congress , the representative of the radical wing of our party , who have split our organization by nominating another candidate for President — Mr. Stevens will give their views .

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: Pompously to the Committee .The radical wing of the party , gentlemen , has been the only creative force within it — and is the only thing that gives it an excuse for being to-day .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Firmly .Which means that you think that I am superfluous and always have been — I thank you — proceed !

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: We denounce first your policy of reconstruction in the South as weak and vacillating — a civil and military failure . As the army advances , the South should be held as conquered soil , its civilization torn up by the roots , the property of the Southern white people confiscated and given to the negroes . The ballot must be taken from the whites and given to their slaves . We demand this just vengeance and we will be content with nothing less !

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Stevens , I greet with shame your demands ! Surely the vastness of this war , its grim battles , its heroism , its anguish , its sublime earnestness , should sink all schemes of revenge . Before the grandeur of its simple story our children will walk with uncovered heads . Conquered soil ! The South has never been out of this Union . Secession was null and void from the beginning . I say to the South now , as I have always said : “ Come back home ! You can have peace at any moment , by simply laying down your arms and submitting to the National Authority . ” When the South lies crushed at our feet , God 's vengeance shall be enough .

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: The life of our party , sir , demands that the Negro be given the ballot and made the ruler of the South . This is not vengeance . It is justice — it is patriotism .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: The Nation cannot be healed until the South is healed . Let the gulf be closed in which we bury strifes and hatreds . The good sense of our people will never consent to your scheme of vengeance .

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: The people have no sense ! And a new fool is born every second .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I have an abiding faith in their honesty and good purpose . I have trusted the people before , and they have not failed me .

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: Bah ——!

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I can n't tell you , Stevens , how your venomous plans sicken me . I 'd rather work with you than fight you , if it 's possible . But the line is drawn now — we 've got to fight — and I 'm not afraid of you .

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: You had better listen ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I 'll suffer my right arm to be severed from my body before I 'll sign one measure of revenge on a brave , fallen foe !

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: I have always known you had a sneaking admiration for the South !

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I love the South — it is a part of this Union ! And when the curse of slavery is lifted , it should be the garden spot of the world — I love every foot of its soil — every hill and valley , and every man , woman and child in it . I am an American !

lg.l: The kind of an American that makes the election of your opponent ,
General George B. McClellan , a certainty ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Well , who would you put in my place ?He faces RAYMOND and STEVENS , and dead silence follows .Come on — out with his name ——!They remain silent .You can n't name him ? Let me try to nominate him for you —— On a platform of proscription and revenge , the hanging of rebel leaders , the confiscation of the property of the white people of the South and its bestowment upon the negroes , the taking of the ballot from the whites and setting their slaves to rule over them — on this program I resign as your candidate and nominate for President , the Hon . Thaddeus Stevens ——

lg.l: No ! No ! No ! Not by a damn sight ! To hell with Stevens !

div.stage: LINCOLN quietly laughs and STEVENS angrily lifts his hand to quiet them .

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: Now that you 've had your joke — let me remind you that the radical wing of the Republican Party has already named General John C. Fremont against you ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: To the Committee .What say you , gentlemen ——? Shall I resign in favor of the bolter who attempted to dictate to you your platform and your candidate before your convention met ? Do you ask me to resign in favor of General Fremont ?

sp.speaker: THE COMMITTEE
sp.p: No ! No ! Down with the bolter ! To the devil with Fremont . No ! No ! No ! Damnation — no ——

div.stage: RAYMOND quiets the uproar .

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: I am not asking you to nominate Fremont . We split the party and named Fremont because we would n't have you . Get off the ticket and we will withdraw Fremont and put up a man who can be elected ! Whatever the chances of General Fremont at this moment the election of McClellan on a Democratic Copperhead Platform is conceded by your own party councils . McClellan is even now choosing his Cabinet ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: They say it is not wise to count chickens before they 're hatched — we still have our chance !

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: You have no chance ! You have already been weighed and found wanting ! In the Congressional election , what happened ?— your majorities were wiped out . Maine cut you down from nineteen thousand to four ! The Democrats swept Ohio . Indiana deserted us . In Pennsylvania even , we lost by four thousand . New York elected Horatio Seymour against us . New Jersey turned you down . Wisconsin was a tie . In your own state of Illinois , the Democrats won by seventeen thousand ——!

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Even so , Stevens — the ballots in this election have not yet been counted ! My faith in the ultimate good sense of the people is unshaken . You can fool some of the people all the time . You can fool all of the people sometimes . But you can n't fool all the people all the time !

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: That 's why we ask you to get off the ticket ! You are to-day the most unpopular man who ever sat in the Presidential chair . For the first time in our history the effigy of a living President — your effigy — has been publicly burned in the streets of American towns and cities , amid the curses and jeers of the men who elected you ! Your administration is a failure — your conduct of the war a series of blunders ——

lg.l: For example ——

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: Furiously .For one thing — you have never yet chosen a successful General . The South has not changed Commanders since Jeff Davis appointed Robert E. Lee . In thirty days of the last campaign in a series of massacres , Lee has killed and wounded sixty-two thousand of our men — more than he himself commanded — and Grant has only reached the point where McClellan stood in 1862 . He could have marched there by McClellan 's old line without the loss of a man . Washington is piled with the wounded , the dying and the dead . Your mail is choked with letters demanding the removal of this butcher as our Commander , and you refuse — why ?

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Smiling calmly .Well , now that you 've really let off steam , I think you 'll feel better , Stevens ——!

lg.l: I demand , sir , an answer to my question — why have you not removed
Grant ?

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Quickly .Because I can n't spare him ! He is the one General we have developed who knows how to fight — his business is not to reach any particular spot where McClellan stood . McClellan was generally standing somewhere — he was a great engineer — of the stationary type —— Grant is a fighter . His business is to find and destroy Lee 's army — and his sledge hammer blows are winning this war !

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: Winning — is he ? And yet Lee sends a division under Jubal Early and reconquers the Valley of Virginia — invades Maryland and Pennsylvania , throws his shells into Washington and burns the home of one of your Cabinet ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: And if old Jubal Early had been a little earlier , he would have burned Washington , too — but thank God , Grant got here in time — did n't he ? What have you got to say to that ?

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: That Lee 's strategy has been superb , his moral victory complete ! He holds Grant by the throat while he invades the North , and shells our Capitol — a feat that not one of your generals has yet done for Richmond in four years — and still you cling to Grant ——!

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Angrily .Now , I 'm going to talk plain English to you , Stevens . You 're an Abolitionist , and you can n't do Grant justice . Your crowd demanded his removal after the battle of Shiloh — and you made it so hot for me then , I had to appoint General Halleck his superior , to save him for the country . You can n't forget that Grant is a Democrat , and therefore he may vote for McClellan against our party , in this election !

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: I 've heard that he is for McClellan .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Exactly ! And you can n't forget that his wife is a Southern woman whose dowry was in Slaves , and therefore at this moment , Grant is constructively a slaveholder , whose slaves I have not freed ——

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: I protest ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: It 's no use — I know the process of your mind — I can see the wheels go round inside ! You tell me that the star of Grant has set in a welter of blood before Lee 's army . I do not believe it . I know that miles of hospital barracks are the witnesses of our agony . I know that every city , town and village is in mourning . From these stricken homes there has arisen a storm of protest against the new leader of the army . The word butcher is bandied from lip to lip . They tell me that Grant is merely a bulldog fighter — that he can win only as long as thousands are poured into his ranks to take the place of the dead — They tell me that he has no genius , no strategy , no skill . My reply to this is simple but unanswerable . We must fight to win . Grant is the ablest general we have developed . His losses are appalling — but the struggle is on now to the bitter end ! Our resources are exhaustless . The South cannot replace her fallen soldiers — and therefore her losses are fatal ! If we continue to fight , five millions cannot whip twenty millions — the end is certain — and we 're now locked in the last death grapple before — VICTORY !

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: It 's a waste of time to talk ——!

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I 've thought so from the first , but I 've tried to be polite ——

lg.l: Good day , sir ——!
Good day , Stevens ——
You know this meeting reminds me of what happened in Illinois once ——

sp.speaker: STEVENS
sp.p: Throwing up his hands in anger .I wo n't hear it , sir ! You and your stories are sending this country to hell — it 's not more than a mile from there now !

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I believe it is just a mile from here to the Capitol where you sit !

sp.speaker: RAYMOND
sp.p: You will consider our request , Mr. President ?

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Raymond , this is the most brutal insult ever offered to a man in my position in the history of this country . I 'm going to waive the insult and give your request my earnest thought . If I can save the Union — that 's the only question — that 's the only question !

sp.speaker: RAYMOND
sp.p: You will give us your answer to-day ?

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Firmly .No . I must have time to think . As I 've listened to you , the conviction grows on me that the life of the Union may be bound with mine now , and I 'm not going to give up — without a fight .

lg.l: We cannot leave Washington without your answer , Mr. President .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: You 'll get it in due time .

sp.speaker: RAYMOND
sp.p: The time is short ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: It may be long enough yet , to save the Nation ——

sp.speaker: RAYMOND
sp.p: Firmly .The Committee must take definite action before we leave — we will give you ten days to decide ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I understand . Good day , gentlemen !

lg.l: Good day , Mr. President .

div.stage: LINCOLN stands erect , with NICOLAY watching them go in silence . When the last man is gone , he turns to NICOLAY .

lg.l: It 's infamous , John ! Infamous !
Do n't tell her the nasty things old Thad said to me . It will hurt her .

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Of course not .

lg.l: What is it , Father — what did they say ?
lg.stage: He pauses and she presses him tremblingly .
lg.l: What did they say ? What did they say ?

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: With dreamy look .They told me in plain English that I am the most unpopular man in the United States — that my conduct of the war is a series of blunders , my administration a failure !

lg.l: Oh !— is that all !

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: What more ——?

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: I thought they had something important to tell you ——

lg.l: MRS. LINCOLN
That is of no importance , because it 's a lie ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: But , if they believe it , and millions of people believe it ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Well , they wo n't . I 've something important to ask of you — Betty Winter 's in my room and wants to bring her lover here to see you alone for an hour to-night ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I 'll see Miss Betty Winter any time — she is my good friend — make it nine o'clock .

lg.l: At nine — do n't forget now !
I 'll not ——
John , is General McClellan at home ?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: I saw him to-day , sir .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Go to his house immediately and tell him I want to see him here at eight o'clock tohYpppHeNnight . Say that it 's a matter of the gravest importance — both to him and to the country — he can n't refuse .

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Say to General McClellan that I would come to him but for the fact that it would attract attention which I wish to avoid . It will be the best for both that this meeting should not be known . Ask him to come in a closed carriage . Assure him that you will meet him at the door and he will see no one but me ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: You can n't take me into your confidence , Chief ?

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Pauses .Partly — I 'm going to put McClellan to the supreme test , John . If he will make me one pledge on the Copperhead issue which I will ask of him , I 'll name for this Committee a candidate they 're not looking for — I 'll give them the surprise of their life — so help me God !

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: I do n't think the General will give that pledge , sir .

lg.stage: Gazing upward and folding his arms .
lg.l: I wonder !— I wonder if he will !
I wonder if he will ——

div.stage: CURTAIN

div.head: ACT II

stage.stage: SET SCENE : The same as Act I at a quarter to eight the same evening .

AT RISE : EDWARD , the old Doorman , is straightening the furniture in the room . He clumsily clears the floor of a litter of letters and places them in the corner with the unopened bag . He draws the heavy draperies of the windows and adjusts them so that no ray of light can reach the outside . MRS. LINCOLN enters and watches him fix the draperies .

sp.speaker: Edward ——!
sp.p: EDWARD

div.stage: Jumping in fright .

lg.l: MRS. LINCOLN
What on earth are you doing in here ——?
Just — er drawin ’ — er the curtains , Madam .
These curtains have n't been drawn in a year ——
I-don'thYpppHeNthinkhYpppHeNtheyhYpppHeNhavehYpppHeNeither ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: You know they have n't !

lg.l: MRS. LINCOLN
Who told you to draw them ?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Colonel Nicolay !

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Where is he ?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Down-stairs , on the door .

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: In your place ?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Yes 'm ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: While you 're up here acting as house maid ?

lg.l: Well , so it seems , Madam ——
What does this mean ?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: I do not know , Madam ——

lg.l: And you have n't the slightest idea — I suppose ?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Not the slightest . My experience as Doorman of the White House has taught me that my first duty is to obey the orders of my Chief ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Mr. Lincoln asked you to remain on duty here to-night ?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Bows .Asked me as a particular personal favor to him , that I remain on duty until eight o'clock and dismiss all the other White House attendants ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: The guard has been dismissed !

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Yes , Madam , both of them — inside and out .

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Ask Colonel Nicolay to come here ——

sp.speaker: Yes 'm ——
sp.p: MRS. LINCOLN

div.stage: Sharply .

lg.l: EDWARD
Right away , Madam !

div.stage: MRS. LINCOLN quickly examines the President 's desk , looking for a memorandum of his appointments — she finds a pad and reads .

lg.l: At eight o'clock —— ——
At nine o'clock — Miss Betty Winter ——

div.stage: NICOLAY enters hurriedly .

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: What is it , Madam ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Who has this mysterious appointment with the President at eight o'clock — the name is blank .

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: I am forbidden to discuss it with any one .

sp.speaker: Indeed !
sp.p: NICOLAY

lg.l: MRS. LINCOLN
Do you know who is coming ?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Yes ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Do you know the subject for discussion at this meeting ?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: I wish to God I did ——

div.stage: LINCOLN enters and glances at his wife in surprise .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Will you go back to the door , John ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: At once — sir ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: And tell Edward I 'm much obliged to him for staying , but he can go now ——

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Yes , sir ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: See that he goes before our visitor arrives . I have asked him to say nothing about this appointment .

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: You can trust him implicitly , sir ——

div.stage: NICOLAY exits .

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: But , you can n't trust your wife , to-night , it seems ——

lg.l: Well , you know you 're a woman , Mother ——
LINCOLN
Amen ! So say I !

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: You 're afraid to tell me — who this man is ——?

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I may tell you to-morrow ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: When — you'vehYpppHeNmadehYpppHeNsomehYpppHeNfatalhYpppHeNblunder ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I 'll make no mistake this time ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Then why are you afraid of my woman 's intuition ——

lg.l: I 'm not afraid of your intuition , Mother ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Thank you .

lg.l: I did n't say it !——
— But you know you do talk too much sometimes !

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Angrily .And I 'm going to say something to you now . I thought this morning that you would treat those scoundrels with the contempt they deserve when they dared to ask you to sacrifice yourself and the cause of the Union to the ambitions of some traitor behind them .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: No ! No ! They 're honest in what they say ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Furious .You 're too good and simple for this world ! Do n't you know that some schemer is behind all this ——?

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Maybe —— It 's not a crime , Mother , for a man to aspire to high office , if the bee 's in his bonnet . You know I 've felt it tickle me lots of times ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Do n't — do n't — do n't say such foolish things . You need a guardian . You kept three men in your Cabinet who used their position to try to climb into the Presidency over your head . And you did n't kick them out .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: The country needed them .

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: With earnest dignity .The country needs you — you are the man , and the only man who has the simple common sense to save this Union first , and settle all other questions afterwards ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: That may be so — too ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: Tell me one thing — is the man who has this appointment at eight the traitor whom Raymond 's Committee is trying to put in your place ——?

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: No ! Yet — if there is anywhere a better man who can render the country a greater service than I can , he ought to be in my place ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: But do n't you see that it is n't really the man who can give the greater service who will win in such a treacherous fight ? It 's the liar and the hypocrite who may win .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I have no right in such an hour to think of my own ambitions . My personal desire for a second term is the biggest thing in my life , God knows ——He pauses as his voice breaks — he struggles a moment and lifts his hand as if to throw off an obsession with a determined smile .And yet , my personal desire is a petty thing ! My duty to-day is the biggest thing in the world !

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: You wo n't take my advice and send these men about their business ?

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Mary , I 've got to fight this thing out alone , with myself and God ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LINCOLN
sp.p: I sometimes think , Father , that you 're the stubbornest man the Lord ever made !

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I 've got to be — to do this job ——

div.stage: MRS. LINCOLN exits .
LINCOLN paces the floor with his arms locked behind him in tense thought .
NICOLAY enters .

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: The carriage is approaching , sir .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: The coast is clear ?

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Yes . Edward has gone ——He pauses .You , of course , realize , Chief , the importance of a cool head in dealing with McClellan ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I wo n't lose my temper , John .

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: McClellan may lose his ——

lg.l: I 'll watch out ——
That report of Baker 's on the Copperhead Societies ——
Under that paper weight , sir ——

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: Oh , yes , I see ——Picks up report , glances at it , and lays it back on his desk .I 'm ready — bring him in . See that we are not interrupted , and when he goes , I 'll not need you any more to-night . I 'll let in the young people myself , at nine o'clock .

sp.speaker: NICOLAY
sp.p: Yes , sir .

div.stage: NICOLAY exits and LINCOLN returns to his desk and writes .

NICOLAY enters with GENERAL MCCLELLAN . The General is thirty-eight years old , dressed in a uniform of immaculate cut , flashing with gold . While his figure is short and stocky , in striking contrast to the President , he is a man of commanding appearance , and gives one the impression of a born leader of men . He enters with quick military precision and salutes with studied formality the President as his superior officer . The President answers his salute , as NICOLAY exits .

sp.speaker: LINCOLN
sp.p: I suggest , General McClellan , that we forget for the moment that I am the Commander in Chief of the Army and Navy — and we have a little heart to heart talk in a perfectly informal way ——

sp.speaker: McCLELLAN
sp.p: Stiffening .May I enquire , Mr. President , at once , to what I owe this extraordinary summons ?

lg.l: Will you be seated , General ——?
